One hundred fifty years ago, Abraham Lincoln signed a law that transformed agriculture and education, and transformed America along the way.

Named after its congressional sponsor, the Morrill Act of 1862 directed the states to create institutions of higher learning for the study of agriculture and mechanics, and provided 30,000 acres of public land to each state for the purpose.
These land-grant universities include MIT, Cornell, the California state universities and Texas A&M, among many others.
